DataElement.preferredName: Pancreas Positive Surgical Margin Invasive Carcinoma Involvement Surgical Margin Location PancreasMarginLocation
DataElement.preferredDefinition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand.  It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues.  The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food.  Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.:Indicates the presence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.:A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process._One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:A position, site, or point in space where something can be found._Location of Margin associated with a Pancrease Tumor Tissue Sample

It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues.  The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food.  Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. ObjectClass.preferredName: Pancreas Positive Surgical Margin Invasive Carcinoma Involvement
ObjectClass.preferredDefinition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand.  It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues.  The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food.  Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.:Indicates the presence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.:A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.:To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Concepts.definition: An organ behind the lower part of the stomach that is the shape of a fish and about the size of a hand. It is a compound gland composed of both exocrine and endocrine tissues. The endocrine pancreas makes insulin so that the body can use glucose (sugar) for energy. The exocrine pancreas makes enzymes that help the body digest food. Spread all over the pancreas are areas called the Islets of Langerhans. The cells in these areas each have a special purpose. The alpha cells make glucagon, which raises the level of glucose in the blood; the beta cells make insulin; the delta cells make somatostatin. There are also PP cells and D1 cells, about which little is known.
Indicates the presence of tumor cells at the edge of a surgically excised specimen.
A carcinoma that is not confined to the epithelium, and has spread to the surrounding stroma.
To have a connection by participation or association or use; sharing in an activity or process.

Property.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

Concepts.definition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.
A position, site, or point in space where something can be found.

ValueMeaning.preferredDefinition: One of the criteria for assessment of the effectiveness of given surgical procedure in achieving the local control of a neoplasm and the adequacy of tumor removal. It is defined by the tissue plane through which the dissection has been done and the actual or potential neoplastic tissue which has been left outside the boundary of a resected specimen within the patient. There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:Bile ducts are passageways that carry bile. Two major bile ducts come together into a "trunk"-the common bile duct which empties into the upper part of the small intestine (the part next to the stomach).

Concepts.definition: Bile ducts are passageways that carry bile. Two major bile ducts come together into a "trunk"-the common bile duct which empties into the upper part of the small intestine (the part next to the stomach).

There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.

Concepts.definition: Situated farthest from a point of attachment or origin, as of a limb or bone; or directed away from the midline of the body.

There are four types of surgical margins: intracapsular or intralesional, marginal, wide, and radical.:Arranged like rays or radii; radiating from a common center or moving in the direction of a radius; relating to or near the radius.:(RET-row-PAIR-ih-toe-NEE-ul) Having to do with the area outside or behind the peritoneum (the tissue that lines the abdominal wall and covers most of the organs in the abdomen).:Denoting the back surface of the body; at or near the hind end in quadrupeds or toward the spine in primates.

Concepts.definition: Denoting the back surface of the body; at or near the hind end in quadrupeds or toward the spine in primates.
Occurring in, or located in the retroperitoneum.
Arranged like rays or radii; radiating from a common center or moving in the direction of a radius; relating to or near the radius.
